cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who received the most (but not a majority of) electoral votes in 1824
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
In the 1824 United States presidential election, there were four main candidates: John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson, William H. Crawford, and Henry Clay. Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes (99) but did not secure a majority (which would have required at least 131 out of 261 total electoral votes). Since no candidate achieved a majority, the election was decided by the House of Representatives, where John Quincy Adams was ultimately chosen as president.

Answer:
Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes in 1824, with 99 votes.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who received the most (but not a majority of) electoral votes in 1824
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The 1931 election of Sir Cooper Rawson holds the record for the largest majority ever received at a general election (62,253), as well as the most votes received by an individual (75,205).\n', 'The elections of 1876, 1888, 2000, and 2016 produced an Electoral College winner who did not receive at least a plurality of the nationwide popular vote. In 1824, there were six states in which electors were legislatively appointed, rather than popularly elected, so it is uncertain what the national popular vote would have been if all presidential electors had been popularly elected. When no candidate received a majority of electoral votes in 1824, the election was decided by the House of Representatives and so could be considered distinct from the latter four elections in which all of the states had popular selection of electors. The true national popular vote was also uncertain in the 1960 election, and the plurality for the winner depends on how votes for Alabama electors are allocated.\n', 'The 1876 Republican National Convention, was held at Exposition Hall, in Cincinnati, Ohio. On the first Presidential Ballot, Bristow was third, at 113 votes, while James G. Blaine received 285 votes, followed by Oliver P. Morton, at 124 votes. On the fourth Presidential Ballot, Bristow finished second, at 126 votes, his highest number, while Blaine was first, at 292 votes. On the seventh and final Presidential Ballot, Bristow received only 21 votes. Rutherford B. Hayes, was elected the Republican presidential candidate, at 384 votes. Blaine finished a close second at 351 votes.\n', 'The 1876 election is the second of five presidential elections in which the person who won the most popular votes did not win the election, and the only such election in which the popular vote winner received a majority (rather than a plurality) of the popular vote. To date, it remains the election that recorded the smallest electoral vote victory (185–184) and the election that yielded the highest voter turnout of the eligible voting age population in American history, at 81.8%. Despite not becoming president, Tilden was the first Democratic presidential nominee since James Buchanan in 1856 to win the popular vote and the first since Franklin Pierce in 1852 to do so in an outright majority (In fact, Tilden received a slightly higher percentage than Pierce in 1852, despite the fact that Pierce won in a landslide).\n', '"Due to multiple candidates from the same party in the 1824 election (and the party being the only major party at the time), this chart only shows the electoral votes of the winning candidate, even though he did not receive a plurality of the electoral votes and the election was decided in the United States House of Representatives.\n', 'McKinley received a little more than seven million votes, Bryan a little less than six and a half million, about 800,000 in excess of the Democratic vote in 1892. It was larger than the Democratic Party was to poll in 1900, 1904, or 1912. It was somewhat less, however, than the combined vote for the Democratic and Populist nominees had been in 1892. In contrast, McKinley received nearly 2,000,000 more votes than had been cast for Benjamin Harrison, the Republican nominee, in 1892. The Republican vote was to be but slightly increased during the next decade.\n', 'In addition to the candidates listed above, other Federalists received electoral votes between 1796 and 1820. In the 1796 election, Oliver Ellsworth, John Jay, James Iredell, Samuel Johnston, and Charles Cotesworth Pinckney all received at least one electoral vote. Jay also received a single vote in the 1800 election. In the 1816 election, Robert Goodloe Harper, John Marshall, and James Ross all received electoral votes for vice president. In the 1820 election, Richard Stockton, Robert Goodloe Harper, Daniel Rodney, and Richard Rush all received at least one electoral vote for vice president.\n', 'The 46 ballots were the most cast at a convention since 1860.\n', 'Both W. M. Somerville in Bewdley at the 1874 United Kingdom general election and F. R. Lees in Drogheda at the 1852 United Kingdom general election received no votes.\n', 'The majority requirement for election was met in all 13 districts in 1828.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about who received the most (but not a majority of) electoral votes in the 1824 election, we can extract relevant content from the provided passages. Here’s a breakdown of the key points and their roles in understanding the context of the 1824 election:

1. **Electoral Votes and Majority Requirement**:
   - The passage mentions that in the 1824 election, no candidate received a majority of electoral votes, which is crucial for understanding why the election was decided by the House of Representatives. This context is important because it highlights the unique nature of the 1824 election compared to other elections where a clear majority winner was present.

2. **Multiple Candidates from the Same Party**:
   - The passage notes that there were multiple candidates from the same party (the Democratic-Republican Party) in the 1824 election. This detail is significant because it explains why no candidate could secure a majority; the votes were split among several candidates, leading to a situation where the candidate with the most electoral votes did not achieve a majority.

3. **House of Representatives Decision**:
   - The mention of the election being decided by the House of Representatives indicates a critical aspect of the electoral process in the U.S. when no candidate achieves a majority. This is a key historical fact that underscores the importance of the electoral system and its implications for the outcome of elections.

4. **Electoral Vote Distribution**:
   - The passage implies that the electoral votes were distributed among several candidates, which is essential for identifying who received the most votes. Understanding the distribution of votes is crucial for answering the question about who had the most electoral votes.

5. **Uncertainty of National Popular Vote**:
   - The passage discusses the uncertainty of the national popular vote in 1824 due to some electors being appointed rather than elected. This context helps explain the complexities of the electoral process at that time and the challenges in determining a clear winner based on popular support.

### Role of Extracted Content:
- **Contextual Understanding**: The extracted content provides a historical context for the 1824 election, explaining why it was unique and how the electoral system functioned at that time. This understanding is crucial for answering the question accurately.
  
- **Clarification of Terms**: By clarifying what it means to receive "the most but not a majority" of electoral votes, the passages help frame the question in a way that highlights the significance of the electoral vote distribution.

- **Historical Significance**: The details about the House of Representatives' role in deciding the election emphasize the historical significance of the 1824 election and its implications for future elections.

### Conclusion:
From the passages, we can infer that the candidate who received the most electoral votes in the 1824 election was John Quincy Adams, although he did not receive a majority. The context provided by the passages helps clarify the complexities of the electoral process during that election and the factors that contributed to its outcome.

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

In the 1824 United States presidential election, there were four main candidates: John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson, William H. Crawford, and Henry Clay. The election is notable for its unique outcome, as no candidate received a majority of the electoral votes, which at the time required at least 131 out of a total of 261 electoral votes.

1. **Electoral Votes and Majority Requirement**:
   - Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes, totaling 99. However, this was not a majority, which is critical for understanding why the election was ultimately decided by the House of Representatives. The lack of a majority is a key aspect of this election, distinguishing it from others where a clear winner emerged.

2. **Multiple Candidates from the Same Party**:
   - The presence of multiple candidates from the Democratic-Republican Party contributed to the split in electoral votes. This division among candidates is significant because it explains why Jackson, despite having the most votes, could not achieve the majority needed to win outright.

3. **House of Representatives Decision**:
   - Since no candidate achieved a majority, the election was decided by the House of Representatives, where each state delegation cast one vote for one of the top three candidates. John Quincy Adams was ultimately chosen as president, despite Jackson's lead in electoral votes. This underscores the importance of the electoral system and the role of the House in such scenarios.

4. **Electoral Vote Distribution**:
   - Understanding the distribution of electoral votes among the candidates is essential. Jackson's 99 votes were the highest, but the total votes were spread across the four candidates, preventing any from reaching the majority threshold.

5. **Uncertainty of National Popular Vote**:
   - The uncertainty surrounding the national popular vote in 1824, due to some electors being appointed rather than elected, adds complexity to the election's outcome. This context is important for understanding the electoral dynamics of the time and the challenges in determining a clear winner based on popular support.

### Conclusion:
From the enhanced reasoning process, it is clear that Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes in the 1824 election, with a total of 99 votes. However, he did not secure a majority, leading to the election being decided by the House of Representatives, where John Quincy Adams was ultimately elected president.

### Answer:
Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes in the 1824 election, with 99 votes.

Task Description:

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. Identify points of agreement and disagreement among the experts, and analyze how these differing perspectives contribute to a deeper understanding of the topic. Synthesize the insights from the discussion into a cohesive summary that captures the full range of foundational and advanced knowledge. Highlight how these perspectives expand the understanding of the question.

By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on the 1824 Election**

**Expert 1: Historical Context Specialist**
The 1824 election is particularly fascinating because it was marked by a unique set of circumstances. There were multiple candidates from the same party, the Democratic-Republicans, which led to a fragmented electoral vote. This fragmentation is crucial because it meant that no candidate received a majority of the electoral votes, which is a key point in understanding the election's outcome. The election was ultimately decided by the House of Representatives, which adds another layer of complexity to the situation.

**Expert 2: Electoral Process Analyst**
I agree with Expert 1 about the fragmentation of the vote. In fact, the lack of a majority in the electoral votes is what makes this election distinct from others. The fact that electors were appointed in some states rather than elected by popular vote also complicates our understanding of the electorate's will. This uncertainty about the popular vote is a significant factor that historians must consider when analyzing the legitimacy of the election outcome.

**Expert 3: Political Science Scholar**
Building on what both experts have said, it’s important to note that John Quincy Adams received the most electoral votes in 1824, but he did not secure a majority. This situation illustrates the complexities of the electoral system at the time and raises questions about the democratic process. The election serves as a case study for understanding how electoral systems can lead to outcomes that might not reflect the popular will.

**Expert 4: Constitutional Expert**
I would like to add that the 1824 election also highlights the limitations of the electoral system as it was designed. The decision by the House of Representatives to choose the president when no candidate received a majority of electoral votes underscores the potential for political maneuvering and the influence of party politics. This situation led to the so-called "Corrupt Bargain" between Adams and Henry Clay, which has had lasting implications for American political history.

**Synthesis of Perspectives**
From this discussion, we can see a consensus on the significance of the 1824 election as a pivotal moment in American political history. The fragmentation of the Democratic-Republican Party, the lack of a majority in the electoral votes, and the subsequent decision by the House of Representatives all contribute to a deeper understanding of the electoral process and its implications for democracy.

The differing perspectives highlight the multifaceted nature of the election. While some experts focus on the historical context and the electoral mechanics, others emphasize the political ramifications and the implications for future elections. This comprehensive view allows us to appreciate the complexities of the electoral system and the challenges it poses to achieving a truly representative democracy.

**Conclusion**
In summary, the 1824 election serves as a critical case study in American electoral history, illustrating the potential pitfalls of the electoral system and the importance of understanding the historical and political context in which elections occur. John Quincy Adams, having received the most electoral votes without a majority, stands as a symbol of the complexities inherent in the electoral process, prompting ongoing discussions about representation and legitimacy in American democracy.

Answer:

**Discussion-Enhanced Reasoning Process:**

In the 1824 United States presidential election, four main candidates competed: John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson, William H. Crawford, and Henry Clay. The election was notable for its unique circumstances, including the fragmentation of the Democratic-Republican Party, which resulted in no candidate receiving a majority of the electoral votes. 

Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes, totaling 99, but this was not enough to secure a majority, which required at least 131 out of the 261 total electoral votes. The lack of a majority led to the election being decided by the House of Representatives, where John Quincy Adams was ultimately chosen as president. This outcome highlights the complexities of the electoral system at the time, as well as the influence of political maneuvering, particularly the controversial "Corrupt Bargain" between Adams and Clay.

The discussion among experts emphasizes several key points:

1. **Fragmentation of Votes**: The presence of multiple candidates from the same party led to a divided electorate, making it impossible for any candidate to achieve a majority. This fragmentation is critical for understanding the election's outcome.

2. **Electoral Process and Legitimacy**: The method of electing electors in some states, which involved legislative appointment rather than popular vote, raises questions about the legitimacy of the electoral outcome. This uncertainty complicates the analysis of the electorate's true preferences.

3. **Political Ramifications**: The election serves as a case study for the potential pitfalls of the electoral system, illustrating how it can lead to outcomes that do not reflect the popular will. The subsequent decision by the House of Representatives underscores the influence of party politics and the potential for political maneuvering.

4. **Historical Significance**: The 1824 election is viewed as a pivotal moment in American political history, prompting ongoing discussions about representation, legitimacy, and the effectiveness of the electoral system.

**Conclusion**: 
In summary, while Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes in the 1824 election, with a total of 99, he did not achieve a majority. The election's outcome, decided by the House of Representatives, reflects the complexities and challenges of the electoral process at that time. This case illustrates the importance of understanding the historical and political context in which elections occur, as well as the implications for future electoral systems and democratic representation.

**Answer**: 
Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes in the 1824 election, totaling 99 votes, but did not secure a majority.

To address the question of who received the most (but not a majority of) electoral votes in the 1824 election, we can extract relevant information from the provided passages. Here’s a consolidation of the pertinent content:

1. **Electoral Votes in 1824**: The 1824 election is notable because no candidate received a majority of the electoral votes. The election was ultimately decided by the House of Representatives, which is a unique circumstance compared to other elections where a clear winner emerged from the Electoral College.

2. **Multiple Candidates**: The presence of multiple candidates from the same party (the Democratic-Republican Party) contributed to the lack of a majority. This situation complicates the analysis of electoral outcomes, as it reflects a divided party rather than a straightforward contest.

3. **Electoral Vote Distribution**: The passage indicates that the chart showing electoral votes only reflects the winning candidate, emphasizing that the winner did not achieve a plurality of the electoral votes. This suggests that understanding the distribution of votes among candidates is crucial for analyzing electoral outcomes.

4. **Historical Context**: The uncertainty regarding the national popular vote in 1824, due to some states appointing electors rather than electing them, adds another layer of complexity to the analysis of electoral outcomes. This context is important for understanding the implications of the electoral vote distribution.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

The extracted information can enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities in several ways:

1. **Understanding Complex Electoral Dynamics**: By recognizing that multiple candidates from the same party can lead to a divided vote, the model can better analyze scenarios where electoral outcomes are not straightforward. This understanding can be applied to other elections with similar dynamics.

2. **Interpreting Electoral Outcomes**: The distinction between receiving the most electoral votes and achieving a majority is crucial for logical reasoning about election results. The model can learn to differentiate between these concepts and understand their implications for governance and representation.

3. **Contextual Analysis**: The historical context surrounding the 1824 election, including the method of electing electors, allows the model to appreciate how electoral processes can vary and influence outcomes. This contextual awareness is vital for making informed inferences about electoral systems in different historical and political settings.

4. **Causal Relationships**: The model can develop a better understanding of causal relationships in electoral politics, such as how the number of candidates and the method of electing electors can affect the likelihood of achieving a majority. This understanding can be generalized to analyze other political scenarios where multiple factors interact to produce complex outcomes.

who received the most (but not a majority of) electoral votes in 1824

In the 1824 United States presidential election, there were four main candidates: John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson, William H. Crawford, and Henry Clay. Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

In the 1824 United States presidential election, there were four main candidates: John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson, William H. Crawford, and Henry Clay. The election is historically significant because it was the first time in U.S. history that no candidate received a majority of the electoral votes, which necessitated a decision by the House of Representatives.

1. **Electoral Votes Distribution**: Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes, totaling 99. However, this was not a majority, as a majority would have required at least 131 out of the 261 total electoral votes available at that time.

2. **Impact of Multiple Candidates**: The presence of multiple candidates from the same party (the Democratic-Republican Party) contributed to the divided electoral outcome. This division among candidates complicated the electoral process and led to the unique situation where the election was decided in the House of Representatives rather than through a clear majority in the Electoral College.

3. **House of Representatives Decision**: Since no candidate achieved a majority, the election was ultimately decided by the House of Representatives, where John Quincy Adams was selected as president. This outcome underscores the importance of understanding the electoral system's mechanics and how they can lead to unexpected results.

4. **Historical Context and Uncertainty**: The electoral process in 1824 was further complicated by the fact that some states appointed electors rather than electing them. This uncertainty regarding the national popular vote adds complexity to the analysis of the election and highlights the importance of considering different electoral systems and their implications.

5. **Causal Relationships**: Understanding the causal relationships in this election—such as how the number of candidates and the method of electing electors influenced the outcome—can help in analyzing other elections. The model can learn that a divided party can lead to unexpected electoral results, which is a valuable insight for future reasoning about political dynamics.

### Answer:
Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes in the 1824 election, with a total of 99 votes, but he did not secure a majority, which would have required at least 131 votes. The election was ultimately decided by the House of Representatives, where John Quincy Adams was chosen as president.

Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.

who received the most (but not a majority of) electoral votes in 1824

['The 1931 election of Sir Cooper Rawson holds the record for the largest majority ever received at a general election (62,253), as well as the most votes received by an individual (75,205).\n', 'The elections of 1876, 1888, 2000, and 2016 produced an Electoral College winner who did not receive at least a plurality of the nationwide popular vote. In 1824, there were six states in which electors were legislatively appointed, rather than popularly elected, so it is uncertain what the national popular vote would have been if all presidential electors had been popularly elected. When no candidate received a majority of electoral votes in 1824, the election was decided by the House of Representatives and so could be considered distinct from the latter four elections in which all of the states had popular selection of electors. The true national popular vote was also uncertain in the 1960 election, and the plurality for the winner depends on how votes for Alabama electors are allocated.\n', 'The 1876 Republican National Convention, was held at Exposition Hall, in Cincinnati, Ohio. On the first Presidential Ballot, Bristow was third, at 113 votes, while James G. Blaine received 285 votes, followed by Oliver P. Morton, at 124 votes. On the fourth Presidential Ballot, Bristow finished second, at 126 votes, his highest number, while Blaine was first, at 292 votes. On the seventh and final Presidential Ballot, Bristow received only 21 votes. Rutherford B. Hayes, was elected the Republican presidential candidate, at 384 votes. Blaine finished a close second at 351 votes.\n', 'The 1876 election is the second of five presidential elections in which the person who won the most popular votes did not win the election, and the only such election in which the popular vote winner received a majority (rather than a plurality) of the popular vote. To date, it remains the election that recorded the smallest electoral vote victory (185–184) and the election that yielded the highest voter turnout of the eligible voting age population in American history, at 81.8%. Despite not becoming president, Tilden was the first Democratic presidential nominee since James Buchanan in 1856 to win the popular vote and the first since Franklin Pierce in 1852 to do so in an outright majority (In fact, Tilden received a slightly higher percentage than Pierce in 1852, despite the fact that Pierce won in a landslide).\n', '"Due to multiple candidates from the same party in the 1824 election (and the party being the only major party at the time), this chart only shows the electoral votes of the winning candidate, even though he did not receive a plurality of the electoral votes and the election was decided in the United States House of Representatives.\n', 'McKinley received a little more than seven million votes, Bryan a little less than six and a half million, about 800,000 in excess of the Democratic vote in 1892. It was larger than the Democratic Party was to poll in 1900, 1904, or 1912. It was somewhat less, however, than the combined vote for the Democratic and Populist nominees had been in 1892. In contrast, McKinley received nearly 2,000,000 more votes than had been cast for Benjamin Harrison, the Republican nominee, in 1892. The Republican vote was to be but slightly increased during the next decade.\n', 'In addition to the candidates listed above, other Federalists received electoral votes between 1796 and 1820. In the 1796 election, Oliver Ellsworth, John Jay, James Iredell, Samuel Johnston, and Charles Cotesworth Pinckney all received at least one electoral vote. Jay also received a single vote in the 1800 election. In the 1816 election, Robert Goodloe Harper, John Marshall, and James Ross all received electoral votes for vice president. In the 1820 election, Richard Stockton, Robert Goodloe Harper, Daniel Rodney, and Richard Rush all received at least one electoral vote for vice president.\n', 'The 46 ballots were the most cast at a convention since 1860.\n', 'Both W. M. Somerville in Bewdley at the 1874 United Kingdom general election and F. R. Lees in Drogheda at the 1852 United Kingdom general election received no votes.\n', 'The majority requirement for election was met in all 13 districts in 1828.\n']

In the 1824 United States presidential election, there were four main candidates: John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson, William H. Crawford, and Henry Clay.

3. **Multiple Candidates from the Same Party**: The presence of multiple candidates from the same party (the Democratic-Republican Party) contributed to the division of electoral votes, making it difficult for any single candidate to achieve a majority. This context is essential for understanding the dynamics of the election.

This distinction is crucial for accurately answering the question about who received the most electoral votes.

This context is important for grasping the broader implications of the election outcome.

- Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes (99) in the 1824 election but did not achieve a majority.
- The election was ultimately decided by the House of Representatives, where John Quincy Adams was chosen as president.
- The presence of multiple candidates from the same party contributed to the electoral outcome.

Andrew Jackson received the most electoral votes in the 1824 election, with 99 votes, but he did not secure a majority. The election was ultimately decided by the House of Representatives, which selected John Quincy Adams as president.

question_info.question: who received the most (but not a majority of) electoral votes in 1824
passages:
The 1931 election of Sir Cooper Rawson holds the record for the largest majority ever received at a general election (62,253), as well as the most votes received by an individual (75,205).
The elections of 1876, 1888, 2000, and 2016 produced an Electoral College winner who did not receive at least a plurality of the nationwide popular vote. In 1824, there were six states in which electors were legislatively appointed, rather than popularly elected, so it is uncertain what the national popular vote would have been if all presidential electors had been popularly elected. When no candidate received a majority of electoral votes in 1824, the election was decided by the House of Representatives and so could be considered distinct from the latter four elections in which all of the states had popular selection of electors. The true national popular vote was also uncertain in the 1960 election, and the plurality for the winner depends on how votes for Alabama electors are allocated.
The 1876 Republican National Convention, was held at Exposition Hall, in Cincinnati, Ohio. On the first Presidential Ballot, Bristow was third, at 113 votes, while James G. Blaine received 285 votes, followed by Oliver P. Morton, at 124 votes. On the fourth Presidential Ballot, Bristow finished second, at 126 votes, his highest number, while Blaine was first, at 292 votes. On the seventh and final Presidential Ballot, Bristow received only 21 votes. Rutherford B. Hayes, was elected the Republican presidential candidate, at 384 votes. Blaine finished a close second at 351 votes.
The 1876 election is the second of five presidential elections in which the person who won the most popular votes did not win the election, and the only such election in which the popular vote winner received a majority (rather than a plurality) of the popular vote. To date, it remains the election that recorded the smallest electoral vote victory (185–184) and the election that yielded the highest voter turnout of the eligible voting age population in American history, at 81.8%. Despite not becoming president, Tilden was the first Democratic presidential nominee since James Buchanan in 1856 to win the popular vote and the first since Franklin Pierce in 1852 to do so in an outright majority (In fact, Tilden received a slightly higher percentage than Pierce in 1852, despite the fact that Pierce won in a landslide).
"Due to multiple candidates from the same party in the 1824 election (and the party being the only major party at the time), this chart only shows the electoral votes of the winning candidate, even though he did not receive a plurality of the electoral votes and the election was decided in the United States House of Representatives.
McKinley received a little more than seven million votes, Bryan a little less than six and a half million, about 800,000 in excess of the Democratic vote in 1892. It was larger than the Democratic Party was to poll in 1900, 1904, or 1912. It was somewhat less, however, than the combined vote for the Democratic and Populist nominees had been in 1892. In contrast, McKinley received nearly 2,000,000 more votes than had been cast for Benjamin Harrison, the Republican nominee, in 1892. The Republican vote was to be but slightly increased during the next decade.
In addition to the candidates listed above, other Federalists received electoral votes between 1796 and 1820. In the 1796 election, Oliver Ellsworth, John Jay, James Iredell, Samuel Johnston, and Charles Cotesworth Pinckney all received at least one electoral vote. Jay also received a single vote in the 1800 election. In the 1816 election, Robert Goodloe Harper, John Marshall, and James Ross all received electoral votes for vice president. In the 1820 election, Richard Stockton, Robert Goodloe Harper, Daniel Rodney, and Richard Rush all received at least one electoral vote for vice president.
The 46 ballots were the most cast at a convention since 1860.
Both W. M. Somerville in Bewdley at the 1874 United Kingdom general election and F. R. Lees in Drogheda at the 1852 United Kingdom general election received no votes.
The majority requirement for election was met in all 13 districts in 1828.
